questions.question_text: Full Legal Name of Your Company
questions.guidance_text: Enter your company's complete registered name as it appears on your incorporation certificate and GST registration. This name will be used on all policy documents and must match your legal records exactly.

Provide your company's complete registered office address including street, building name, city, state, and pin code. This address should match your incorporation documents and will be used for all official correspondence.
questions.placeholder: e.g., 501, Tower B, Business Plaza, Andheri East, Mumbai, Maharashtra - 400093

questions.guidance_text: Enter the primary mobile number for insurance-related communications. This should be of a senior decision-maker who can authorize policy changes and handle claims.
Provide the primary email address for receiving policy documents and important updates. Use an official company email that is regularly monitored by the finance or risk management team.
Enter your company website if available. This helps insurers understand your business profile and market presence, which can positively impact your premium rates.
Enter your company's 10-character PAN (Permanent Account Number). This is essential for tax compliance and verification of your business identity with government records.
Provide your Corporate Identification Number (CIN) if you're a company, or LLP identification number if you're an LLP. This 21-character alphanumeric code helps verify your company's legal status.
Describe your main business activities, products or services offered, and key markets served. This helps insurers understand your trade credit risk profile based on your industry and customer base.
questions.placeholder: e.g., We manufacture and export cotton textiles to USA and Europe, serving major retail chains with annual contracts

questions.guidance_text: Enter the full name of the person who will be the primary point of contact for this insurance policy. This should be someone with decision-making authority regarding credit management.
Specify the job title or position of the contact person. This helps insurers understand their authority level and ensures communications reach the right person.

questions.question_text: Do you have existing trade credit insurance?
questions.guidance_text: Indicate if you currently have or previously had trade credit insurance. Having prior coverage often results in better premium rates as it shows risk awareness.
Name the insurance company that currently provides or previously provided your trade credit insurance coverage.
Enter your current or most recent trade credit insurance policy number. This helps in verifying your claims history and continuity of coverage.
Specify the coverage period of your existing/previous policy (from date to date). Continuous coverage without gaps often leads to better terms.
Enter the maximum coverage limit of your existing/previous trade credit insurance policy in rupees. This helps assess if you need increased or decreased coverage.
If you're switching from another insurer, explain why. Common reasons include better coverage terms, premium rates, or service quality. This helps the new insurer understand your expectations.
questions.placeholder: e.g., Seeking better coverage for international buyers and more competitive premium rates

questions.question_text: What is your primary business activity?
questions.guidance_text: Select the category that best describes your main business activity. Your industry type significantly influences credit risk assessment and premium calculation.

Enter your total revenue for the last completed financial year before any deductions. This figure helps determine your business size and appropriate coverage limits. Use the figure from your audited financial statements.
Enter your projected revenue for the current financial year. This helps insurers understand your growth trajectory and ensure adequate coverage for your expanding business.

questions.question_text: Percentage of Credit Sales to Total Sales
questions.guidance_text: Enter the percentage of your total sales made on credit terms (not immediate payment). For example, if ₹70 out of every ₹100 in sales is on credit, enter 70. Higher credit sales mean higher risk exposure.

questions.question_text: Average Credit Period Offered to Customers (in days)
questions.guidance_text: Enter the typical number of days you give customers to pay after delivery or invoice date. Standard terms range from 30 to 90 days. Longer credit periods increase your risk exposure.
Enter the longest payment term you offer to any customer, even if only to select premium clients. This helps insurers understand your maximum risk exposure period.
Enter the total number of customers to whom you currently extend credit terms. A diverse customer base typically means lower concentration risk and may lead to better premium rates.

questions.question_text: Percentage of Sales to Top 5 Customers
questions.guidance_text: Calculate what percentage of your total sales comes from your five largest customers. High concentration (over 50%) indicates higher risk if one major customer defaults.
Select all regions where your customers are located. Different markets have varying payment cultures and economic risks, affecting your premium calculation.
Describe the main industries your customers belong to (e.g., retail, automotive, pharmaceuticals). Customer industry health affects their ability to pay and your credit risk.
questions.placeholder: e.g., Primarily retail chains (40%), automotive manufacturers (30%), and e-commerce platforms (30%)

questions.question_text: Do you have a formal credit management policy?
questions.guidance_text: Indicate if you have documented procedures for approving credit limits, monitoring payments, and collecting overdue accounts. Having formal policies often results in better premium rates.

questions.question_text: Do you check customer creditworthiness before extending credit?
questions.guidance_text: Indicate if you verify customer financial health through credit reports, references, or financial statements before offering credit terms. This risk management practice can reduce premiums.
Select all methods you use to assess customer creditworthiness. Using multiple verification methods shows robust risk management and may improve your insurance terms.
Enter the total amount currently owed to you by all customers. This is the sum of all unpaid invoices regardless of their age. This figure helps determine your immediate coverage needs.
Enter the amount of receivables that are current or less than 30 days past the invoice date. These are typically considered healthy receivables with low default risk.
Enter the amount of receivables that are 31-60 days old. These require monitoring but are often still within acceptable payment terms for many industries.
Enter the amount of receivables that are 61-90 days old. These are approaching concerning levels and may require active collection efforts.
Enter the amount of receivables that are 91-180 days old. These are significantly overdue and have higher default risk, requiring immediate collection action.
Enter the amount of receivables over 180 days old. These are considered high-risk or potentially bad debts and may need to be written off.

questions.question_text: Have you experienced any bad debts in the last 3 years?
questions.guidance_text: Indicate if you've had to write off any customer debts as uncollectable in the past three years. Past losses help insurers assess your risk profile and claims likelihood.

questions.question_text: Total Bad Debts in Last 3 Years (in ₹)
questions.guidance_text: Enter the total amount of customer debts you've written off as uncollectable in the last three years. This helps assess your historical loss rate.

questions.question_text: Number of Bad Debt Cases in Last 3 Years
questions.guidance_text: Enter how many separate customers defaulted resulting in bad debts over the last three years. Multiple small losses may indicate systemic issues in credit management.

questions.question_text: Details of Major Bad Debts (if any)
questions.guidance_text: Briefly describe significant bad debt cases including customer name, amount, reason for default, and recovery efforts made. This helps insurers understand the nature of your past losses.
questions.placeholder: e.g., XYZ Traders - ₹1,500,000 in 2023, company went bankrupt; attempted legal recovery but minimal assets available

questions.question_text: Have you filed any trade credit insurance claims before?
questions.guidance_text: Indicate if you've ever claimed on a trade credit insurance policy. Claims history affects your risk rating but having insurance shows risk awareness.
Provide details of past insurance claims including dates, amounts claimed, amounts recovered, and claim reasons. Full disclosure is mandatory for valid coverage.
questions.placeholder: e.g., Claimed ₹800,000 in March 2023 for customer insolvency, received ₹640,000 (80% coverage) after deductible

questions.guidance_text: Select the type of coverage you need. Whole turnover policies cover all customers and often have better rates, while selective coverage lets you insure specific high-risk accounts only.
Enter the maximum amount you want the insurance to cover across all customers. This is typically 10-15% of your annual turnover or your average monthly outstanding receivables.
Select what percentage of the loss you want covered. Higher indemnity means more coverage but higher premiums. Standard coverage is 80-85%, meaning you bear 15-20% of any loss.
Enter the amount you're willing to bear before insurance coverage kicks in. Higher deductibles reduce premiums but increase your out-of-pocket expense during claims.

questions.question_text: Waiting Period Preference (days after due date)
questions.guidance_text: Select how long after payment due date you must wait before filing a claim. Shorter waiting periods mean faster claims but higher premiums. Standard is 90-120 days.
Pre-shipment coverage protects you if a customer cancels an order after you've incurred production costs. Essential for custom manufacturing or large export orders.

questions.question_text: Do you need Political Risk Coverage (for exports)?
questions.guidance_text: Political risk coverage protects against losses due to war, government actions, or currency inconvertibility in buyer's country. Essential for exports to developing or unstable markets.

questions.question_text: List of Top 10 Customers Requiring Coverage
questions.guidance_text: List your 10 largest customers by exposure, including company name, location, typical credit limit, and payment terms. Insurers may check these customers' creditworthiness individually.
questions.placeholder:
e.g., 1. ABC Corp, Mumbai - Credit limit ₹50,00,000, 60 days terms
2. XYZ Ltd, Delhi - Credit limit ₹30,00,000, 45 days terms

questions.question_text: Do any customers have overdue amounts currently?
questions.guidance_text: Indicate if any customers currently have payments overdue beyond their credit terms. High overdue amounts may affect coverage terms or require special underwriting.
List customers with significant overdue amounts, including customer name, overdue amount, days overdue, and collection status. This helps insurers assess current risk exposure.
questions.placeholder: e.g., PQR Enterprises - ₹15,00,000 overdue by 45 days, in active follow-up, expecting payment by month-end

questions.guidance_text: Describe the main products or services you sell on credit. Different products have varying risk profiles - perishables and fashion items typically have higher risk than industrial goods.
questions.placeholder: e.g., Industrial machinery spare parts, electronic components, and maintenance services

questions.question_text: Are your products/services customized or standardized?
questions.guidance_text: Indicate the level of customization in your offerings. Highly customized products have higher risk as they're harder to resell if a customer defaults.

questions.question_text: Do you have contracts/purchase orders for credit sales?
questions.guidance_text: Indicate if you have formal contracts or purchase orders before extending credit. Written agreements strengthen your legal position in case of disputes and may reduce premiums.

questions.question_text: Do you retain title to goods until payment?
questions.guidance_text: Retention of title (ROT) clauses allow you to reclaim goods if payment isn't made. This security measure can significantly reduce your loss exposure and insurance premiums.
Select all payment methods you accept from credit customers. Secure methods like Letters of Credit reduce risk, while open account terms increase exposure.

questions.question_text: Do you use credit insurance for export financing?
questions.guidance_text: Banks often provide better financing terms if receivables are insured. Indicate if you use or plan to use trade credit insurance to improve your working capital financing.
Enter the name of your primary business bank. Some insurers have partnerships with banks that may provide additional benefits or streamlined claim processes.
Indicate if you're currently in legal proceedings with any customers over payment disputes. Ongoing litigation may affect coverage for those specific customers.
Provide details of any ongoing legal cases including customer name, disputed amount, and current status. Full disclosure is required for valid insurance coverage.
questions.placeholder: e.g., Case against MNO Traders for ₹25,00,000, filed in Commercial Court Mumbai, hearing scheduled next month

questions.guidance_text: Enter the year your company was incorporated or started operations. Companies with longer track records typically get better insurance terms due to proven stability.
Enter your 15-character GST identification number. This is required for tax compliance and helps verify your business registration and credit transactions.
If you're an exporter/importer, enter your 10-character IEC number issued by DGFT. This is mandatory if you need coverage for international trade transactions.
Upload your last 2 years' audited balance sheet and P&L statements. These help insurers assess your financial stability and ability to absorb losses. PDF format preferred (Max 10MB).
Upload a current receivables aging report showing all outstanding amounts by customer and age brackets. This should be not older than 30 days. Excel or PDF format (Max 5MB).

questions.question_text: Upload Customer List with Credit Limits
questions.guidance_text: If available, upload a detailed list of all credit customers with their approved credit limits and payment terms. This helps in faster underwriting. Excel format preferred (Max 5MB).
Upload your company's documented credit management policy showing approval processes, credit limits, collection procedures, etc. PDF or Word format (Max 5MB).
If you have a budget in mind for annual insurance premium, please specify. Trade credit insurance typically costs 0.1% to 0.5% of insured turnover depending on risk factors.
Select when you want the insurance coverage to begin. Allow at least 7-10 days from today for underwriting and policy issuance process.
Select your preferred policy duration. Annual policies are standard, but multi-year policies may offer premium discounts and price protection.

questions.question_text: How did you hear about us?
questions.guidance_text: This helps us understand how businesses find our trade credit insurance solutions and improve our services.
Share any specific coverage needs, concerns about particular customers, or questions about trade credit insurance. This helps us customize the solution for your business.
questions.placeholder: e.g., Need coverage for a new large export order to African markets, concerned about political stability

questions.guidance_text: By checking this box, you declare that all information provided is true and complete, and you consent to verification of details and credit checks as needed for underwriting.
questions.placeholder: I declare the information provided is accurate and complete
